messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-Discussion] Heathers
messages.messageBody:
<<<So the AB government licenced them but doesn't cover their care? At least
in BC it's part of the medical plan, so pretty much anyone can have a
midwife.
Tia>>>

Yup. They licensed them so that they could have hours of paper work, stupid rules that make their work less effective, and have to pay $15,000.00 Plus a Year in insurance. I was seriously thinking of going into midwifery before but I couldn't deal with the crap that's dealt out. I preferred the old days when they just did the best they could and the Dr.s stayed out of their way. There are perks know though. They can write prescriptions and admit patient to the hospital and the OB no longer has jurisdiction over the patient. Some of them also get to have a reason to charge more.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-Discussion] Heathers
messages.msgSnippet: ... She moved to BC afterwards as did two others.  Was she Blond, early-mid thirties two sons born early -mid 90 s?? Not the one I was talking about.  She was
messages.messageBody:
> Ooo I had a Midwife named Heather attend my second birth, first at home.
She moved to BC afterwards as did two others. Was she Blond, early-mid
thirties two sons born early -mid 90's??

Not the one I was talking about. She was in Victoria doing her training.
She's got a teenaged daughter, I think. When she finished her training, the
local midwives had decided that there were enough midwives and wouldn't let
her practice here. The College of Midwives has a huge amount of power, some
of the politics I was talking about. She ended up moving to the mainland,
maybe White Rock.

All the midwives in Alberta have changed since the government became
involved. When I had the first at home it was $800.00, then two years later
after the regulations were in the process of taking over $1200, Then two
years later $2000. Because of that I ended up looking into UAbirth but
kinda chickened out at the last minute, then I had a very odd labour(for me)
and Baby arrived before the midwife. So she charged us only for the visits
and a 'house call'. Not bad. I miss my first two midwives though. :-(

So the AB government licenced them but doesn't cover their care? At least
in BC it's part of the medical plan, so pretty much anyone can have a
midwife.
Tia

"They that can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety
deserve neither liberty nor safety." Ben Franklin
leschke@...

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-Discussion] Heathers
messages.msgSnippet: Ooo I had a Midwife named Heather attend my second birth, first at home.   She moved to BC afterwards as did two others.  Was she Blond, early-mid thirties two
messages.messageBody:
Ooo I had a Midwife named Heather attend my second birth, first at home. She moved to BC afterwards as did two others. Was she Blond, early-mid thirties two sons born early -mid 90's?? All the midwives in Alberta have changed since the government became involved. When I had the first at home it was $800.00, then two years later after the regulations were in the process of taking over $1200, Then two years later $2000. Because of that I ended up looking into UAbirth but kinda chickened out at the last minute, then I had a very odd labour(for me) and Baby arrived before the midwife. So she charged us only for the visits and a 'house call'. Not bad. I miss my first two midwives though. :-(

Teresa
----- Original Message -----
From: Heather Hall
To: unschooling-discussion@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, August 02, 2003 10:57 AM
Subject: [Unschooling-Discussion] Heathers


Lol - it's funny to have a common first name, but then to add a common
last name to it ;) I do some doula work, and I too ended up at a
'Heather' birth. Me, the birthing mom, and 2 nurses were all named
Heather.
On Saturday, August 2, 2003, at 10:33 AM,
Unschooling-Discussion@yahoogroups.com wrote:

> ps I find it ironic that you asked these questions. My daughter's
> first and
> favourite midwife is Heather Hall. <g> My Heather was so
> disappointed when
> that Heather moved away.
>
--
Heather, mom to
Harriet 12.15.99
Crispin 01.25.02
heatherette@...
